DIV1.P: As it is performed at the THEATRE ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN.
DIV1.L: Nam ni dixerint ea, quae adolescentuli
Probent, soli in theatris relinquentur.
DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for W. GRIFFIN, at Garrick's Head, in Catharine-street, Strand, 1770.

DIV1.HEAD: TO HIS GRACE THE DUKE OF GRAFTON.
DIV1.P:
I Beggleave to recommend a trifling per∣formance to Your notice; nothing but my venturing to approach Your Grace on this occasion without introduction, could excuse my addressing you without a name: by this kind of sophistry, my Lord, we that set∣up for Poets attempt to palliate one pre∣sumption by another. As I have strong temptations to plead for the honor I now assume, so, I hope, I am not totally without pretensions to it. As an humble son of that Alma Mater, who has now bestowed on Your Grace the most honorable adoption, which maternal approbation had to give, I
flatter myself that I stand in some degree of alliance to you; and if there be any thing in these scenes that deserves the name of Genius, I am happy in acquainting the world that I drew it from the same fountain, and, nearly, at the same period with Your Grace; though not in the same proportion.

As I only seek, by this offering, to amuse a leisure-hour, I have no right either to speak to Your Grace, or of Your Grace, as a Minister. Nevertheless, my Lord, in these ill-tempered times, I must be allowed to say, that there is some merit when your fortune needs no addition, and your rank cannot re∣ceive any, in standing-forth the servant and the sufferer of your country: I say the suf∣ferer, my Lord, because in your station you have to combat not only the envy▪ but the ingratitude of mankind.

In times of peace the Muses, more espe∣cially, look for protection at the thrones of Princes, and in the closets of Ministers. In seasons of public tranquillity, when good order and good humour obtain in a nation, the great may find an ear even for such trifles as I now lay before You. Did these times,
my Lord, answer that Description, I should have much to say to Your Grace on the Sub∣ject of the Stage, so applicable to noble uses, and of the low ebb at which Genius now stands, so much in need of cultivation; but these are topicks too harmonious for an aera that seems to delight in discord; and all the merit I can claim with Your Grace and the public is, that at a time when all other ano∣nymous writers have been scattering the seeds of discontent and disturbance, I have used my best endeavours in the following scenes to lead such of my countrymen, as have attended their representation, into a short paroxysm of complacency and good humour. I have the honor to be

CLOSER.SALUTE: YOUR GRACE's most obedient And most humble Servant,

LG.L: VARIOUS the Shifts os Authors▪ now-a-days,
For Operas, Farces, Pantomimes▪ and Plays;
Some scour each Alley of the Town for Wit,
Begging from Door to Door the offal Bit;
Plunge in each Cellar, tumble every Stall,
And scud, like Taylors, to each House of Call;
Gut every Novel, strip each Monthly Muse,
And pillage Poets Corner of its News:
That done, they melt the stale Farrago down,
And set their Dish of Scraps before the Town;
Boldly invite you to their pilfer'd Store,
Cram you, then wonder you can eat no more.
Some, in our English Classicks deeply read,
Ransack the Tombs of the illustrious Dead;
Hackney the Muse of Shakespeare, o'er and o'er,
From Shoulder to the Flank, all drench'd in Gore.
Others to foreign Climes and Kingdoms roam
To search for what is better found at Home:
The recreant Bard, oh! scandal to the Age!
Gleans the vile refuse of the Gallic Stage.
Not so, our Bard—To-night, he bids me say,
You shall receive and judge an English Play.
From no Man's Jest he draws felonious praise,
Nor from his Neighbour's Garden crops his Bays;
From his own Breast the filial Story flows;
And the free Scene no foreign Master knows:
Nor only tenders he his Work as new;
He hopes 'tis good, or wou'd not give it You:
True homely ware, and made of homely stuff,
Right British Drugget, honest, warm and rough.
No station'd Friends he seeks, no hird applause;
But constitutes you Jurors in his Cause.
For Fame he writes—Shou'd Folly be his doom,
Weigh well your Verdict, and then give it home:
Shou'd you applaud, let that Applause be true;
For, undeserv'd, it shames both him and you.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: WHO but has seen the celebrated strife,
Where Reynolds calls the Canvass into Life▪
And, 'twixt the Tragic▪ and the comic Muse,
Courted of both, and dubious where to chuse,
Th' immortal Actor stands?—Here we espy
An awful Figure, pointing to the Sky;
A grave, sublime, commanding▪ Form she bears;
And in her Zone an unsheath'd Dagger wears.
On t'other Side, with sweet, attractive▪ Mien,
The playful Muse of Comedy is seen:
She, with a thousand soft, bewitching Smiles,
Mistress of Love, his yielding Heart beguiles;
(For where's the Heart so harden'd, to withstand
The fond Compulsion of so fair a Hand?)
Oh! would she he here bestow those winning Arts!
This Night we'd fix her Empire in your Hearts;
No tragic Passions shou'd deface the Age,
But all shou'd catch good Humour from the Stage:
The storming Husband, and imperious Wife,
Shou'd learn the Doctrine of a quiet Life;
The plodding Drudge shou'd here at Times resort,
And leave his stupid Club, and stummy Port;
The pensive Politician, who foresees
Clouds, Storms, and Tempests, in the Calms of Peace;
The scribbling Tribe, who vent their angry Spleens
In Songs, Prints, Pamphlets, Papers, Magazines;
Lucius, and Anti-Lucius, Pros and Con's,
The List of Placets, and of Placet-nons;
The mobbing Vulgar, and the ruling Great,
And all who storm, and all who steer the State;
Here should forget the Labours of the Day,
And laugh their Cares, and their Complaints away:
The Wretch of Jonathan's, who crush'd with Shame,
Crawls lamely out from India's desp'rate game,
Safely might speculate within these Walls;
For here, while you approve, Stock never falls:
Pleas'd then indulge the Efforts of To-night,
Nor grudge to give, if you've receiv'd, delight.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: SCENE, The Sea Coast of CORNWALL.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A rocky shore, with a fisherman's cabbin in the cliff: a violent tempest with thunder and lightning: a ship discover'd stranded on the coast. The characters enter after having looked-out of their cabbin, as if waiting for the abatement of the storm.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: IT blows a rank storm; 'tis well, father, we haul'd the boat ashore before the weather came on; she's safe bestow'd, however, let what will happen.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Ay, Philip, we had need be provident: except that poor skiff, my child, what have we left in this world that we can call our own?

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: To my thoughts now we live as happily in this poor hut, as we did yonder in the great house, when you was 'squire Belfield's principal tenant, and as topping a farmer as any in the whole county of Cornwall.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Ah, child!—

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: Nay, never droop; to be sure, father, the 'squire has dealt hardly with you; and a mighty point, truly, he has gained; the ruin of an honest man. If those are to be the uses of a great estate, Heaven continue me what I am.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Ay, ay, brother, a good conscience in a coarse drugget is better than an aching heart in a silken gown.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Well, children, well, if you can bear misfortunes patiently, 'twere an ill office for me to repine; we have long till'd the earth for a subsistence; now, Philip, we must plough the ocean; in those waves lies our harvest; there, my brave lad, we have an equal inheritance with the best.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: True, father, the sea that feeds us, provides us an habitation here in the hollow of the cliff; I trust, the 'squire will exact no rent for this dwelling—Alas! that ever two brothers should have been so opposite as our merciless landlord, and the poor young gentleman they say is now dead.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Sirrah, I charge you, name not that unhappy youth to me any more; I was endeavouring to forget him and his misfortunes, when the sight of that vessel in distress brought him afresh to my remembrance; for, it seems, he perished by sea; the more shame upon him, whose cruel∣ty and injustice drove him thither; but come—the wind lulls apace; let us launch the boat, and make a trip to yonder vessel; if we can assist in light'ning her, perhaps, she may ride it out.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: 'Tis to no purpose; the crew are coming ashore in their boat, I saw them enter the creek.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Did you so? then do you and your sister step into the cabbin; make a good fire, and provide such fish and other stores as you have within: I will go down and meet them; whoever they may be, that have suffer'd this mis∣fortune on our coasts, let us remember, children, never to regard any man as an enemy, who stands in need of our protection.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P:
I'm strongly tempted to go down the creek too; if father should light on any mischief—well, for once in my life I'll disobey him; sister, you can look to matters
within doors; I'll go round by the point, and be there as soon as he.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Do so, Philip; 'twill be best.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV3.STAGE: GOODWIN re-enters, follow'd by FRANCIS and several sailors carrying goods and chests from the wreck.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: This way, my friends, this way; there's stowage enough within for all your goods.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Come, bear a hand, my brave lads, there's no time to lose; follow that honest man, and set down your chests where he directs you.

SP.SPEAKER: SAILOR.
SP.P: Troth I care not how soon I'm quit of mine; 'tis plaguy heavy.

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SAILOR.
SP.P: Here's a pretty spot of work! plague on't, what a night has this been! I thought this damn'd lee-shore wou'd catch us at last.

SP.SPEAKER: SECOND SAILOR.
SP.P: Why 'twas unpossible to claw her off; well, there's an end of her—The charming Sally Privateer!—Poor soul; a better sea-boat never swam upon the salt sea.

SP.SPEAKER: THIRD SAILOR.
SP.P: I knew we shou'd have no luck after we took-up that woman there from the packet that sunk along side us.

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SAILOR.
SP.P: What, Madam Violetta, as they call her? why, 'tis like enough—But hush, here comes our captain's nephew; he's a brave lad and a seaman's friend, and, between you and me (boatswain's whistle)—But hark we are call'd—Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: That ever fortune shou'd cast us upon this coast! Francis.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Have the people landed those chests we brought off with us in the boat?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: They have, Sir; an old fisherman, whom we met, has shewn us here to a cavern in the clif, where we have stow'd them all in safety.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: That's well. Where's my uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: On board; no persuasions can prevail on him to quit the ship, which, he swears, will lift with the tide; his old crony▪ the master is with him, and they ply the casks so briskly, that it seems a moot point, which fills the fastest, they, or the wreck.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Strange insensibility! but you must bring him off by force then, if there is no other way of saving him; I think o'my conscience he is as indifferent to danger as the plank he treads on; we are now thrown upon my un∣natural brother's estate; that house, Francis, which you see to the left, is his; and what may be the consequence if he and my uncle shou'd meet, I know not; for such has been Captain Ironsides' resentment on my account, that he has declared war against the very name of Belfield; and, in one of his whimsical passions, you know, insisted on my laying it aside for ever; so that hitherto▪ I have been known on board by no other name, than that of Lewson.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P:
'Tis true, Sir; and I think 'twill be adviseable to con∣tinue the disguise, as long as you can. As for the old captain, from the life he always leads on shore, and his impatience to get on board again▪ I think 'tis very possible
an interview between him and your brother may be pre∣vented.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I think so too. Go then, Francis, and conduct the old gentleman hither; I see Violetta coming.

Sure there is something in that woman's story uncom∣monly mysterious—Of English parents—born in Lisbon▪—her family and fortune buried in the earthquake—so much she freely tells; but more I am convincd remains untold, and of a melancholy sort: she has once or twice, as I thought, seem'd disposd to unbosom herself to me; but it is so painful to be told of sorrows one hasn't power to relieve, that I have hitherto avoided the discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Well Madam, melancholy still? stil that face of sorrow and despair? twice shipwreck, and twice rescued from the jaws of death, do you regret your preservation▪ and have I incur'd your displeasure by prolonging your ex∣istence?

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Not so, Mr. Lewon; such ingratitude be far from me▪ can I forget when the vessel, in which I had sail'd from Portugal, founder'd by your side, with what noble, what benevolent ardour you flew to my assistance? regardful only of my safety, your own seem'd no part of your care.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Oh, no more of this; the preservation of a fellow-creature is as natural as self-defence: you now, for the first time in your life, breathe the air of England—a rough reception it has given you; but be not, therefore, dis∣couragd; our hearts, Violetta, are more accessible than our shores; nor can you find inhospitality in Britain, save in our climate only.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: These characteristicks of the nglish may be just; I take my estimate from a less favorable example.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Villany, Madam, is the growth of every soil; nor can I, while yonder habitation is in my view, forget that ng∣land has given birth to monsters that disgrace humanity; but this I will say for my countrymen, that, where you can point-out one rascal with a heart to wrong you, I will produce fifty honest fellows ready and resolute to redress you.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Ah!—But on what part of the English coast is it that we are now landed?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: On the coast of Cornwall.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Of Cornwall is it? You seem to know the owner of that house; are you wel acquainted with the country hereabouts?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Intimately; it has been the cradle of my infancy, and, with little interruption, my residence ever since.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: You are amongst your friends then no doubt; how fortunate is it, that you will have their consolation and assistance in your distress.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Every moment will bring them down to the very shores; this brave, humane, this hospitable people will flock, in crouds, to your relief; your friends, Mr. Lewson—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: My friends, Violetta!—must I confess it to you, I have no friends—those rocks, that have thus scatter'd my treasures, those waves, that have devoured them, to me are not so fatal, as hath been that man, whom Nature meant to be my nearest friend.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: What, and are you a fellow-sufferer then? is this the way you reconcile me to your nation? are these the friends of humankind? why don't we fly from this un∣generous, this ungrateful country?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Hold, Madam; one villain, however base, can no more involve a whole nation in his crimes, than one example, however dignisied, can inspire it with his virtues: thank Heaven, the worthless owner of that mansion is yet with∣out a rival.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: You have twice directed my attention to that house; 'tis a lovely spot; what pity that so delicious a retirement should be made the residence of so undeserving a being!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: It is indeed▪ a charming place, and was once the seat of hospitality and honour; but its present possessor, Andrew Belfield—Madam, for Heaven's sake, what ails you▪ you seem suddenly disorder'd—Have I said—

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: No, 'tis nothing; don't regard me, Mr. Lewson, I am weak and subject to these surprizes; I shal be glad how∣ever to retire.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: A little repose I hope will relieve you; within this hut some accommodation may be found; lean on my arm.
SP.STAGE: [Leads her to the door of the cabbin.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Heaven defend me! do my eyes deceive me? 'tis wond'rous like his shape, his air, his look—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: What is your astonishment, friend? Do you know me▪ If it was not for that habit, I shou'd say your name is Goodwin.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: 'Tis he; he is alive! my dear young master, Mr. Bel∣field! Yes, Sir, my name is Goodwin: however changd my appearance, my heart is still the same, and overflows with joy at this unexpected meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Give me thy hand, my old, my honest friend; and is this sorry hole thy habitation?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: It is.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: The world▪ I see▪ has frown'd on thee sionce we parted.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Yes, Sir: but what are my misfortunes? you must have undergone nnumerable hardships▪ and now, at last, shipwreckd on your own coast! Well, but your vessel is not totally lost, and we will work night and day in saving your effects.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Oh, as for that, the sea gave all, let it take back a part; I have enough on shore not to envy my brother his fortune. But there is one blessing, master Goodwin, I own I should grudge him the possession of—There was a young lady—

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: What, Sir, hav'n't you forgot Miss Sophia?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Forgot her! my heart trembles while I ask you, if she is indeed, as you call her, Miss Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: She is yet unmarried, tho' every day we expect—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: 'Tis enough; Fortune, I acquit thee! Happy be the winds that threw me on this coast, and blest the rocks that receiv'd me! Let my vessel go to pieces; she has done her part in bearing me hither, while I can cast myself at the feet of my Sophia, recount to her my unabaiting passion, and have one sair struggle for her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P:
Once more I am alone. How my heart sunk when Lewson pronounced the name of Belfield▪ It must be he, it must be my false, cruel, yet (spite of all my wrongs) be∣loved husband: yes, there he lives▪ each circumstance confirms it; Cornwall, the county; here the sea-coast, and these white craggy cliffs; there the disposition of his seat; the grove, lake, lawn; every feature of the landscape
tallies with the descriptions he has given me of it. What shall I do, and to whom shall I complain? When Lewson spoke of him, it was with a bitterness, that shock'd me▪ I will not disclose myself to him; by what fell from him I suspect he is related to Mr. Belfield—But, hush, I talk to these rocks, and forget that they have ears.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Are you any better, Madam? is the air of any service to you?

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: I am much reliev'd by it: the beauty of that place at∣tracted my attention, and, if you please, we will walk further up the hill to take a nearer view of it.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: Part of the crew enter with IRONSIDES, and SKIFF in the midst of them.

SP.SPEAKER: OMNES.
SP.P: Huzza, huzza, huzza!

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SAILOR.
SP.P: Long life to your honour! welcome ashore noble cap∣tain.

SP.SPEAKER: SECOND SAILOR.
SP.P: Avast there, Jack; stand clear and let his old honour pass; bless his heart, he looks cherly howsomever; let the world wag as it will, he'll never flinch.

SP.SPEAKER: THIRD SAILOR.
SP.P: Not he; he's true English oak to the heart of him; and a fine old seaman-like figure he is.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Ah, messmates, we're all ground: I have been taking a parting cup with the charming Sally—She's gone; but the stoutest bark must have an end; master, here▪ and I▪ did all we cou'd to lighten her; we took leave of her in an officer-like manner.

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SAILOR.
SP.P: Hang sorrow: we know the worst o't, 'tis only taking a fresh cruie; and for my part I'll sail with Captain Iron▪sides as far as there's water to carry me.

SP.SPEAKER: OMNES.
SP.P: So will we all.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Say ye so, my hearts▪ if the wind sits that way, hoist sail, say I; old George will make one amongst you, if that be all; I hate an idle life—So, so: away to your work: to-morrow we'll make a day o't.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Skiff.

SP.SPEAKER: SKIFF.
SP.P: Here, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: I told you, Skiff, how 'twou'd be; if you had luff'd up in time, as I wou'd have had you, and not made so free with the land, this mishap had never come to pass.

SP.SPEAKER: SKIFF.
SP.P: Lord love you, Captain Ironsides, 'twas a barrel of beef to a biscuit the wind had not shifted so direct contrary, as it did; who cou'd have thought it?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Why I cou'd have thought it; every body cou'd have thought it: do you consider where abouts you are, mun? upon the coast of England, as I take it. Every thing here goes contrary both by sea and land—Every thing whips▪ and chops, and changes about like mad in this country; and the people, I think, are as full of vagaries▪ as the climate.

SP.SPEAKER: SKIFF.
SP.P: Well, I cou'd have swor—

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Ay, so you cou'd, Skiff, and so you did, pretty roundly too; but for the good you did by it, you might as wel have puff a whif of tobacco in the wind's face.

SP.SPEAKER: SKIFF.
SP.P: Well, Captain, tho' we have lost our ship, we hav'n't lost our all: thank the fates, we've sav'd treasure enough to make all our sortunes notwithstanding.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Fortunes quotha? what have two such old weather∣beaten fellows▪ as thee and I are to do with fortune; or, indeed, what has fortune to do with us? Flip and tobacco is the only luxury we have any relish for; had we fine houses, could we live in 'em? a greasy hammock has been our birth for these fifty years; fine horses, cou'd we ride em? and as for the fair sex there, that my nephew makes such a pother about, I don't know what thou may'st think of the matter, Skiff, but for my own part, I should not care if there were no such animals in the creation.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Uncle; what cheer, man?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Oh, Bob, is it thee? whither bound now, my dear boy?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Why, how can you ask such a question? We have landed our treasure, sav'd all our friends, and set foot upon English ground; and what business think you can a young fellow like me have, but one?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Pshaw, you're a fool, Bob; these wenches will be the undoing of you; a plague of 'em altogether, say I; what are they good for, but to spoil company, and keep brave fellows from their duty? o'my conscience, they do more mischief to the king's navy in one twelve-month▪ than the French have done in ten; a pack of—but I ha' done with 'em, thank the stars I ha' fairly wash'd my hands of 'em▪ I ha' nothing to say to none of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: SKIFF.
SP.P: Mercy be good unto us! that my wife cou'd but hear your worship talk.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Oh, my dear uncle—

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P:
But I'll veer-away no more good advice after you▪ so even drive as you will under your petticoat-sails;—black, brown, fair, or awny, 'tis all fish that comes in your net:
why▪ where's your reason, Bob, all this here while? where's your religion, and be damn'd to you?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Come, come, my dear uncle, a truce to your philosophy. Go, throw your dollars into yonder ocean and bribe the tempest to be still, you shall as soon reverse the operations of Nature, as wean my heart from my Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Hold, hold, take me right, if, by Sophia, you mean the daughter of Sir Benjamin Dove, I don't care if I make one with you; what say'st thou, boy, shall it be so?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: So, then you think there may be one good woman how∣ever?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Just as I think there may be one honest Dutchman, one sober German, or one righteous methodist. Look'e▪ Bob, so I do but keep single, I have no objection to other people's marrying; but on these occasions, I wou'd manage myself, as I wou'd my ship; not be running her into every odd creek and cranny in the smuggling fashion, as if I had no good credentials to produce; but play fairly▪ and in sight▪ d'ye see; and whenever a safe harbour opens, stand boldly in, boy, and lay her up snug, in a good birth, once for all.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Come then, uncle, let us about it, and you may greatly favour my enterprize, since you can keep the father and mother in play, while I—

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Avast, young man, avast; the father, if you please, without the mother; Sir Benjamin's a passable good com∣panion for a land-man; but for my lady—I'll have nothing to say to my lady; she's his wife, thank the stars, and not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Be it as you will; I shall be glad of your company on any terms.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Say no more then. About ship; if you are bound for that port, I'm your mate: master, look to the wreck, I'm for a fresh cruize.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: The outside of SIR BENJAMIN DOVE's house.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: WHAT, don't I know you; hav'n't you been to me of all mankind the basest?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Not yet, Lucy.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Sure, Mr. Belfield, you wn't pretend to deny it to my face.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: To thy face, child, I will not pretend that I can deny any thing; you are much too handsome to be contra∣dicted.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Pish!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: So! so!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Hav'n't you, faithless as you are, promised me mar∣riage over and over again?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Repeatedly.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: And you have now engaged yourself to the daughter of Sir Benjamin Dove, have you not?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Assuredly.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Let me demand of you then, Mr. Belfield, since you had no honourable designs towards me yourself, why you prevented those of a humbler lover, young Philip, the son of your late tenant, poor Goodwin?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P:
For the very reason you state in your question; because
I had no honourable designs, and he had: you disap∣pointed my hopes, and I was resolved to defeat his.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: And this you thought reason sufficient to expell his father from your farm; to persecute him and his inno∣cent family, till you had accomplished their ruin, and driven them to the very brink of the ocean for their habi∣tation and subsistence?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Your questions, Miss Lucy, begin to be impertinent.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Oh, do they touch you, Sir? but I'll waste no more time with you; my business is with your Sophia; here, in the very spot which you hope to make the scene of your guilty triumphs, will I expose you to her; set-forth your inhuman conduct to your unhappy brother; and de∣tect the mean artifices you have been driven to, in order to displace him in her affections.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: You will?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I will, be assured; so let me pass.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Stay, Lucy, understand yourself a little better; did'nt you pretend to Sophia, that my brother paid his addresses to you; that he had pledgd himself to marry you; nay, that he had—

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Hold, Mr. Belfield, nor further explain a transaction, which, though it reflects shame enough upon me that was your instrument, ought to cover you, who was prin∣cipal in the crime, with treble confusion and remorse.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: True, child, it was rather a disreputable transaction; and 'tis therefore fit no part of it should rest with me: I shall disavow it altogether.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Incredible confidence▪

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P:
We shall see who will meet most belief in the world, you or I; chuse, therefore, your part: if you keep my secret, you make me your friend; if you betray it, you
have me for your enemy; and a fatal one you shall find me. Now enter, if you think fit; there lies your way to Sophia. [She goes into the house.] So! how am I to parry this blow?—what plea shall I use with Sophia?—'twas the ardour of my love—any thing will find pardon with a woman, that conveys flattery to her charms.—After all, if the worst should happen, and I be defeated in this match, so shall I be saed from doing that, which, when done, 'tis probable I may repent of; and I have some in∣timations from within, which tell me that it will be so: I perceive that, in this life, he who is check'd by the rubs of compunction, can never arrive at the summit of prospe∣rity.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: What melancholy, Mr. Belfield? so near your hap∣piness, and so full of thought?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Happiness, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: I'll tell you, Sir; the possession of a lovely girl, with fifty thousand pounds in her lap, and twice fifty thousand virtues in her mind; this I call happiness, as much as mortal man can merit: and this, as I take it, you are destin'd to enjoy.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: That is not so certain, Mr. Paterson; wou'd you be∣lieve it, that perverse hussey, Lucy Waters, who left me but this minute, threatens to transverse all my hopes, and is gone this instant to Sophia with that resolution?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Impossible! how is Miss Waters provided or provoked to do this?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P:
Why 'tis a foolish story, and scarce worth relating to you; but you know, when your letters called me home from Portugal, I found my younger brother in close at∣tendance on Miss Dove; and, indeed, such good use had the fellow made of his time in my absence, that I found it impossible to counterwork his operations by fair and open
approaches; so, to make short of the story, I took this girl Lucy Waters into partnership; and, by a happy device, ruined him with Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: This, Mr. Belfield, I neither know, nor wish to know.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Let it pass then; defeated in these views, my brother, as you know, betook himself to the desperate course of privateering, with that old tar-barrel, my uncle: what may have been his fate, I know not, but I have found it convenient to propagate a report of his death.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: I am sorry for it, Mr. Belfield; I wish nothing was convenient, that can be thought dishonourable.

SP.SPEAKER: BELEIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Nature, Mr. Paterson, never put into any human composition more candour and credulity, than she did into mine; but acquaintance with life has shewn me how im∣practicable these principles are; to live with mankind, we must live like mankind; was it a world of honesty, I should blush to be a man of art.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: And do you dream of ever reaching your journey's end by such crooked paths as these are?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: And yet, my most sage moralist, wonderful as it may seem to thee, true it is, notwithstanding, that after having threaded all these by-ways, and crooked alles, which thy right-lin'd apprehension knows nothing of; after having driven my rival from the field, and being almost in pos∣session of the spoil, still I feel a repugnance in me that all most tempts me to renounce my good fortune, and aban∣don a victory I have struggled so hard to obtain.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P:
I guess'd as much; 'tis your Violetta; 'tis your fair Portuguese that counterworks your good fortune; and I must own to you, it was principally to save you from that improvident attachment, that I wrote so pressingly for your return; but though I have got your body in safe holding, your heart is still at Lisbon; and if you marry Miss Dove, 'tis because Violetta's fortune was demolished
by the earthquake▪ and Sir Benjamin's stands safe upon terra firma.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Pr'ythee, Paterson, don't be too hard upon me: sure you don't suspect that I am married to Violetta.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Married to Violetta! now you grow much too serious, and 'tis time to put an end to the discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: And you grow much too quick-sighted, Mr. Paterson, for my acquaintance. I think he does not quite suspect me of double dealing in this business; and yet I have my doubts; his reply to my question was equivocal, and his departure abrupt—I know not what to think—This I know, that Love is a deity, and Avarice a devil; that Violetta is my lawful wife; and that Andrew Belfield is a villain.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: All abroad this fine day—not a creature within doors.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: Mr. Paterson! hist, Mr. Paterson! a word in your ear, sweet Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Curse on't, she has caught me—Well, Mrs. Kitty.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: Why, I've been hunting you all the house over; my lady's impatient to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Oh, I'm my Lady Dove's most obedient servant—And what are her ladyship's commands, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: Fye, Mr. Paterson; how shou'd I know what her lady∣ship wants with you? but a secret it is, no doubt, for she desires you to come to her immediately in the garden, at the bottom of the yew-tree walk next the warren.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P:
The devil she does—What a pity it is, Mrs. Kitty,
we can't cure your lady of this turn for solitude; I wish you would go with me; your company, probably, will di∣vert her from her contemplations: besides, I shall cer∣tainly mistake the place.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: I go with you, Mr. Paterson! a fine thing truly: I'd have you to know that my character is not to be trusted with young fellows in yew-tree walks, whatever my lady may think of the matter—Besides, I've an assignation in another place.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: What a devilish dilemma am I in! why this is a pe∣remptory assignation—Certain it is, there are some ladies that no wise man should be commonly civil to—Here have I been flattering myself that I was stroking a terma∣gant into humour, and all the while have been betraying a tender victim into love. Love, love did I say? her la∣dyship's passion is a disgrace to the name—But▪ what shall I do?—'tis a pityful thing to run away from a victory; but 'tis frequently the case in precipitate successes, we conquer more than we have wit to keep, or ability to enjoy.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Now could I but meet my Sophia—where can she have hid herself?—Hush; Lady Dove, as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: So, Mr. Paterson, you're a pretty gentleman, to keep a lady waiting here▪ why how you stand?—Come, come, I shal expect a very handsome atonement for this inde∣corum—Why, what, let me look—Ah! who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: A man, madam; and though not your man, yet one as honest and as secret: come, come, my Lady, I'm n tell-tale; be you but grateful, this goes no further.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Lost and undone! young Belfield▪

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: The same; but be not alarmed; we both have our secrets; I am, like you, a votary to Love: favour but my virtuous passion for Miss Dove, and take you your Pa∣terson; I shal be silent as the grave.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Humph!—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Nay, never hesitate; my brother, I know, had your wishes: but wherein has Nature favoured him more than me? And, since Fortune has now made my scale as heavy as his, why should you partially direct the beam?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Well, if it so, and that you promise not to betray me—But this accident has so discomposed me, (plague on't say I) don't press me any further▪ at present; I must leave you; remember the condition of our agreement, and expect my friendship—Oh, I could tear your eyes out▪

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Well, Sir Benjamin, keep your own council if you are wise; I'll do as I would be done by; had I such a wife as Lady Dove, I should be very happy to have such a friend as Mr. Paterson.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: If there is faith in woman, I have seen young Belfield▪ I have beheld his apparition; for what else could it be?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: How, when▪ where? I shal faint with surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: As I crost the yew-tree walk, I saw him pass by the head of the canall towards the house. Alas! poor youth, the injuries I have done him have calld him from his grave.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Injuries, Miss Waters, what injuries have you do him? Tell me; for therein, perhaps, I may be concernd.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Deeply concern'd you are; with the most penitent re∣morse I confess it to you, that his affections to you were pure, honest, and sincere. Yes, amiable Sophia, you was unrivall'd in his esteem; and I, who persuaded you to the contrary, am the basest, the falsest of womankind; every syllable I told you of his engagements to me was a mali∣cious invention: how cou'd you be so blind to your own superiority, to give credit to the imposition, and suffer him to depart without an explanation? Oh, that villain, that villain his brother has undone us all.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Villain do you call him? whither wou'd you transport my imagination? you hurry me with such rapidity from one surprize to another, that I know not where to fix, how to act, or what to believe.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, he is a villain; a most accomplish'd one; and, if I can but snatch you from the snare he has spread for you, I hope it will, in some measure, atone for the in∣juries I have done to you, and to that unhappy youth, who now—O Heavens! I see him again; he comes this way: I cannot endure his sight; alive or dead I must avoid him.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Adorable Sophia! this transport overpays my labours.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Sir, Mr. Belfield, is it you? Oh, support me!—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: With my life, thou loveliest of women! Behold your poor adventurer is returned; happy past compute, if his fate is not indifferent to you; rich beyond measure, if his safety is worthy your concern.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Release me, I beseech you: what have I done! Sure, you are too generous to take advantage of my confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Pardon, me, my Sophia; the advantages I take from your confusion, are not to be purchas'd by the riches of the east: I wou'd not forego the transport of holding you, one minute, in my arms, for all that wealth and greatness have to give.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV3.STAGE: LADY DOVE enters, while BELFIELD JUNIOR is kneeling and embracing SOPHIA.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Heyday! what's here to do with you both?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Ah!—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Confusion! Lady Dove here.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Lady Dove is here, and will take care you shall have no more garden-dialogues. On your knees too—(The fellow was not half so civil to me). Ridi∣culous! a poor beggarly swabber truly—as for you Mrs.—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Hold, Madam, as much of your fury and foul language as you please upon me; but not one hard word against that lady, or by Heavens!—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Come, Sir, none of your reprobate swearing, none of your sea-noises here; I wou'd my first husband was alive, I wou'd he was for your sake. I am surpri'd Miss Dove you have no more regard for your reputation; a delicate swain truly you have chosen, just thrown ashore from the pitchy bowels of a shipwreck privateer▪ Go, go, get you in for shame; your father shall know of these goings∣on, depend on't: as for you, Sir—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: As she is going out, he stops her.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: A word with you, Madam; is this fair dealing? What wou'd you have said, if I had broke in thus upon you and Mr. Paterson?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Mr. Paterson! why you rave▪ what is it you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Come, come, this is too ridiculous: you know your reputation is in my keeping; call to mind what passed between us a while ago, and the engagment you are un∣der on that account.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Very well, truly; and you think to brave this matter out, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Most assuredly; and shall make Sir Benjamin call you to account if you dare to breathe a word against my repu∣tation: incorrigible coxcomb! to think I wou'd keep any terms with you after such an event. Take my word for it, Belfield, you are come home no wiser than you went out; you missed the only advantage you might have taken of that rencounter, and now I set you at defiance: take heed to what you say, or look to hear from Sir Benjamin.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Oh, no doubt on't; how can Sir Benjamin avoid fight∣ing for your sake, when your ladyship has so liberally equip him with weapons▪

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: And so, Sir, 'tis just as I tell you; every thing in this family goes according to the will of the lady: for my own part, I am one of those that hate trouble; I swim with the stream, and make my place as easy as I can.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Your looks, Mr. Jonathan, convince me that you live at your case.

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: I do so, and, therefore, (in spite of the old proverb, "Like master, like man") you never saw two people more different than I and Sir Benjamin Dove. He, Lord help him, is a little peaking puling thing; I am a jolly portable man, as you see. It so happen'd that we both became widowers at the same time; I knew when I was well, and have continued single ever since. He fell into the clutches of—Hark, sure I hear my lady—

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: No, it was nothing. When did the poor gentleman light upon this termagant?

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: Lackaday, 'twas here at the borough of Knavestown, when master had the great contest with 'Squire Belfield, about three years ago: her first husband, Mr. Searcher, was a king's messenger, as they call it, and came down express from a great man about court during the poll; he caught a surfeit, as ill-luck wou'd have it, at the election-dinner; and, before he died, his wife, that's now my lady, came down to see him; then it was master fell in love with her: egad, 'twas the unluckyest job of all his life.
Sir Benjamin calls without.
Jonathan! why Jonathan!

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Hark, you are called!

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: Ay▪ ay▪ 'tis only my master; my lady tells the servants not to mind what Sir Benjamin says, and I love to do as I am bid▪

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Well, honest Jonathan, if you wn't move, I must; by this time I hope my young master is happy with your young mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Why▪ Jonathan, I say. Oh, are you here? why cou'dn't you come when I call'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: Lackaday, Sir, you don't consider how much easier it is for you to call▪ than for me to coe.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: I think, honest Jonathan, when first I knew you, you was a parish-orphan; I prentic'd you out; you run-away from your masters; I took you into my family; you married; I set you up in a farm of my own, stock'd it; you paid me no rent; I receiv'd you again into my service, or rather, I shou'd say, my lady's. Are these things so, or does my memory fail me, Jonathan?

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: Why▪ to be sure, I partly remember somewhat of what your worship mentions.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: If you partly remember something of all this, Jonathan, don't entirely forget to come when I call.
Hoy there! within! what nobody stirring! all hands asleep▪ all under the hatches?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hey-day, who the dickens have we got here? Old Captain Ironsides, as I'm a sinner: who could have thought of this? Run to the door, good Jonathan—nay, hold, there's no escaping now:—what will become of me?—he'll ruin every thing; and throw the whole house into confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: What▪ Sir Ben! my little knight of Malta! give me a buss, my boy. Hold, hold, sure I'm out of my reck∣oning; let me look a little nearer; why, what mishap has befallen you, that you heave out these signals of distress?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P:
I'm heartily glad to see thee, my old friend; but a
truce to your sea-phrases, for I don't understand them: what signals of distress have I about me?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Why that white flag there at your main top-mast head: in plain English, what dost do with that clout about thy pate?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Clout, do you call it? 'tis a little en dshabille, indeed; but there's nothing extraordinary, I take it, in a man's wearing his gown and cap in a morning; 'tis the dress I usually chuse to study in.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: And this hall is your library, is it? Ah! my old friend, my old friend! but, come, I wanted to have a little chat with you, and thought to have drop in at pudding-time, as they say; for though it may be morning with thee, Sir Ben, 'tis mid-day with the rest of the world.—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Indeed, is it so late?—But I was fallen upon an agree∣able tête-a-tête with Lady Dove, and hardly knew how the time passed.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Come, come, 'tis very clear how your time has passed; but what occasion is there for this fellow's being privy to our conversation?—Why don't the lubber stir? what does the fat, lazy▪ oaf stand staring at?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: What shall I say now? was ever any thing so distress∣ing?—Why that's Jonathan, Captain; don't you re∣member your old friend Jonathan?

SP.SPEAKER: JONATHAN.
SP.P: I hope your honour's in good health; I'm glad to see your honour come home again.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Honest Jonathan, I came to visit your master, and not you; if you'll go and hasten dinner, and bring Sir Ben∣jamin his perriwig and cloaths, you'll do me a very ac∣ceptable piece of service: for to tell you the truth, my friend, I hav'nt had a comfortable meal of fresh provision this many a day.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Foregad, you're come to the wrong house to find one.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: And so, Sir Knight, knowing I was welcome, and hav∣ing met with a mishap here, upon your coast, I am come to taste your good cheer, and pass an evening with you over a tif of punch.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: The devil you are! (Aside.)—This is very kind of you; there is no man in England, Captain Ironsides, better pleased to see his friends about him than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Ay, ay, if I did'n't think I was welcome I shou'dn't ha' come.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: You may be assur'd you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: I am assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: You are, by my soul: take my word for it, you are.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Well, well, what need of all this ceremony about a meal's meat, who doubts you?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: You need not doubt me, believe it; I'll only step out and ask my Lady what time she has order'd dinner; or whether she has made any engagement I'm not ap∣priz'd of.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: No, no; engagement! how can that be, and you in this pickle? Come, come, sit down; dinner wn't come the quicker for your enquiry: and now tell me, how does my god-daughter Sophia?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Thank you, heartily, Captain, my daughter's well in health.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: That's well; and how fares your fine new wife? how goes▪ on matrimony? fond as ever, my little amorous Dove▪ always billing, always cooing?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: No, Captain, no, we are totally alter'd in that respect; we shew no fondness now before company; my lady is so delicate in that particular, that from the little notice she takes of me in public, you wou'd scarce believe we were man and wife:

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! why 'tis the very circumstance that wou'd confirm it; but I'm glad to hear it; for of all things un∣der the sun I most nauseate your nuptial familiarities; and, tho' you remember I was fool enough to dissuade you from this match, I'm rejoic'd to hear you manage so well and so wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: No man happier in this life, captain, no man happier; one thing only is wanting; had the kind stars but crown'd our endearments—

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: What, my lady don't breed then?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hush, hush! for Heaven's sake, don't speak so loud; shou'd my lady overhear you, it might put strange things into her head; oh! she is a lady of delicate spirits, ten∣der nerves, quite weak and tender nerves; a small mat∣ter throws her down; gentle as a lamb; starts at a straw; speak loud and it destroys her: oh my friend, you are not us'd to deal with women's constitutions; these hypocon∣driac cases require a deal of management; 'tis but charity to humour them, and you cannot think what pains it re∣quires to keep them always quiet and in temper.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Ay, like enough; but here comes my lady, and in ex∣cellent temper, if her looks don't belie her.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.P: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE, CAPTAIN IRONSIDES, and LADY DOVE.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P:
What's to do now, Sir Benjamin? what's the matter that you send for your cloaths in such a hurry? can't you be
contented to remain as you are? your present dress is well enough to stay at home in, and I don't know that you have any call out of doors.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Gentle as a lamb, Sir Benjamin.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: This attention of yours, my dear, is beyond measure flattering! I am infinitely beholden to you; but you are so taken-up with your concern on my account, that you overlook our old friend and neighbour Captain Ironsides.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Sir Benjamin, you make yourself quite ridiculous: this folly is not to be endur'd; you are enough to tire the patience of any woman living.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: She's quite discompos'd, all in a flutter for fear I shou'd take cold by changing my dress.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Yes I perceive, she has exceeding weak nerves. You are much in the right to humour her.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Sir Benjamin Dove, if you mean that I shou'd stay a minute longer in this house, I insist upon your turning that old porpoise out of it: is it not enough to bring your nauseous sea-companions within these doors, but must I be compell'd to entertain 'em? Foh▪ I shan't get the scent of his tar-jacket out of my nostrils this fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hush, my dear lady Dove, for Heaven's sake, don't shame and expose me in this manner; how can I possibly turn an honest gentleman out of my doors, who has given me no offence in lise?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Marry, but he has tho', and great offence too; I tell you, Sir Benjamin, you are made a fool of.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Nay, now, my dear sweet love be compos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Yes, forsooth, and let a young rambling raking prodi∣gal run away with your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE
SP.P: How, what!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: A fine thing truly to be compos'd—

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Who is it your ladyship suspects of such a design?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Who, Sir? why, who but your nephew Robert▪ you flatter'd us, with a false hope, he was dead; but to our sorrow, we find him alive and return'd: and now you are cajoling this poor simple unthinking man, while your wild Indian, your savage there, is making-off with his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Mercy on us! what am I to think of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: What are you to think! why that is a lye; that you are an ass; and that your wife is a termagant. My nephew is a lad of honour, and scorns to run away with any man's daughter, or wife either, tho' I think there's little danger of that here—As for me, sooner than mess with such a vixen, I'd starve: and so, Sir Benjamin, I wish you a good stomach to your dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Insolent, unmannerly brute, was ever the like heard? And you to stand tamely by: I declare I've a great mind to raise the servants upon him, since I have no other de∣fenders. Thus am I for ever treated by your scurvy companions.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Be pacified, my dear, am I in fault? But for Heaven's sake, what is become of my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P:
Yes, you can think of your daughter; but she is safe enough for this turn; I have taken care of her for one while, and thus I am rewarded for it. Am I a vixen, am I a termagant? Oh, had my first husband, had my poor
dear, dead Mr. Searcher heard such a word, he woud have rattled him—But he—What do I talk of? he was a man: yes, yes, he was, indeed, a man—As for you—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Strain the comparison no farther, Lady Dove; there are particulars, I dare say, in which I fall short of Mr. Searcher.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Short of him ▪ I'll tell you what Sir Benjamin, I valued the dear greyhound that hung at his button-hole▪ more than I do all the foolish trinkets your vanity has lavish'd on me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Your Ladyship, doubtless, was the paragon of wives: I well remember when the poor man laid ill at my borough of Knavestown, how you came flying on the wings of Love, by the Exeter waggon to visit him before he died.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: I understand your sneer, Sir, and I despise it: there is one condition only upon which you may regain my for∣feited opinion; young Belfield, who with this old fellow, has designs in hand of a dangerous nature▪ has treated me with an indignity still greater than what you have now been a witness to. Shew yourself a man upon this occa∣sion, Sir Benjamin.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Any thing, dearest, for peace-sake.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Peace-sake! it is war and not peace which I require—But come, if you will walk this way, I'll lay the matter open to you.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: AND when is this great match of▪ Mr. Belfield' to be?

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Alas! Madam, we look to hear of it every day.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: You seem to consider this event, child, as a misfor∣tune to yourself: however others may be affected by Mr. Belfield's marrying Miss Dove, to you▪ I conceive▪ it must be matter of indifference.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: I have been taught, Madam, to consider no event as matter of indifference to me, by which good people are made unhappy. Miss Sophia is the best young lady li∣ing; Mr. Belfield is—

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Hold, Fanny, do step into the house; in my writing∣box you will find a letter sealed, but without a direction, bring it to me. [Exit Fanny.] I have been writing to this base man; for▪ I want fortitude to support an interview. What, if I unbosom'd myself to this girl, and ntrusted the letter to her conveyance? She seems exceedingly ho∣nest, and for one of so mean a condition, uncommonly sensible; I think, I may safely confide in her.—Well, Fanny.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Here is your letter, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: I thank you; I trouble you too much; but thou art a good-natur'd girl, and your attention to me shall not go unrewarded.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P:
I am happy to wait upon you; I wish I cou'd do or say any thing to divert you; but my discourse can't be very
amusing to a lady of your sort; and talking of this wed∣ding seems to ha made you more melancholy than you was before.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Come hither, child; you have remarked my disquie∣tude, I will now disclose to you the occasion of it: you seem interested for Miss Dove; I too am touch'd with her situation: you tell me, she is the best young lady living.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Oh! Madam, if it were possible for an angel to take a human shape she must be one.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: 'Tis very well; I commend your zeal; you are speak∣ing now of the qualities of her mind.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Not of them alone; she has not only the virtues but the beauty of an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Indeed? Pray, tell me, is she so very handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: As fine a person as you could wish to see.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Tall?

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: About your size, or rather taller.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Fair, or dark-complexion'd?

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Of a most lovely complexion; 'tis her greatest beauty▪ and all pure nature, I'll be answerable; then, her eyes are so soft, and so smiling, and as for her hair—

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Hey-day! why, where are you rambling, child? I am satisfy'd; I make no doubt she is a consummate beauty, and that Mr. Belfield loves her to distraction. [Aside.] I don't lie this girl so well as I did; she is a great talker; I am glad I did not disclose my mind to her; I'll go in and determine on some expedient.

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P:
Alas! poor lady! as sure as can be, she has been cross'd in love; nothing in this world besides cou'd make
her so miserable; but sure I see Mr. Francis; if falling in love leads to such misfortunes, 'tis sit should get out of his way.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Wasn't that your sister, Philip, that ran into the cabbin?

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: I think it was.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: You've made a good day's work o't; the weather com∣ing about so fair, I think we've scarce lost any thing of value, but the ship; didn't you meet the old Captain as you came down to the creek?

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: I did; he has been at Sir Benjamin Dove's here, at Cropley-Castle, and is come back in a curious humour.

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: So! so! I attended my young master thither at the same time; how came they not to return together?

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: That I can't tell—Come, let's go in and refresh our∣selves.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Indeed and indeed, Miss Lucy Waters, these are strong facts which you tell me; and, I do believe no prudent woman wou'd engage with a man of Mr. Andrew Bel∣field's disposition; but what course am I to follow? and how am I to extricate myself from the embarassments of my situation?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Truly, Madam, you have but one refuge that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: And that lies in the arms of a young adventurer. O Lucy, Lucy, this is a flattering prescription; calculated rather to humour the patient▪ than to remove the disease.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Nay, but if there is a necessity for your taking this step—

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Ay▪ necessity is grown strangely commodious of late, and always compels us to do the very thing we have most a mind to.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Well, Madam, but common humanity to young Mr. Belfield—You must allow he has been hardly treated.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: By me, Lucy?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Madam▪—No, Madam, not by you; but 'tis cha∣rity to heal the wounded, though you have not been a party in the fray.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: I grant you!—You are a true female philosopher; you would let Charity recommend you a husband, and a husband recommend you to Charity—But I wnt reason upon the matter; at least, not in the humour I am now; nor at this particular time: no, Lucy, nor in this par∣ticular spot; for here it was, at this very hour, yesterday evening, did young Belfield surprize me.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: And see, Madam, punctual to the same lucky moment, he comes again: let him plead his own cause; you need fear no interruption; my lady has too agreeable an en∣gagement of her own, to endeavour at disturbing those of other people.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Have I then found thee▪ loveliest of women▪ O! So∣phia, report has struck me to the heart; if, as I am told, to-morrow gives you to my brother, this is the last time I am ever to behold you.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Why so, Mr. Belfield? Why should our separation be a necessary consequence of our alliance?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Because I have been ambitious, and cannot survive the pangs of disappointment.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Alas▪ poor man! but you know where to bury your disappointments; the sea is still open to you; and, take my word for it, Mr. Belfield, the man who can live three years, ay, or three months, in separation from the woman of his heart, need be under no apprehensions for his life, let what will befa her.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Cruel, insulting Sophia! when I last parted from you, I flattered myself I had left some impression on your heart—But in every event of my life, I meet a base, in∣jurious brother; the everlasting bar to my happiness—I can support it no longer; and Mr. Belfield, Madam, never can, never shal be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: How, Sir! never shal be mine? What do you tell me? There is but that man on earth▪ with whom I can be happy; and if my fate is such, that he is never to be mine, the world, and all that it contains, will for ever after be indifferent to me.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I have heard enough; farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Farewell, sagacious Mr. Belfield; the next fond fe∣male, who thus openly declares herself to you, will, I hope, meet a more galante reception than I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: How, what! is't possible? O Heaven's!

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: What, you've discover'd it at last? Oh, fie upon you!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Thus, thus, let me embrace my unexpected blessing come to my heart, my fond, o'erflowing heart, and tell me once again that my Sophia will be only mine.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P:
O man, man! all despondency one moment, all rap∣ture the next. No question now but you conceive every difficulty is surmounted, and that we have nothing to do but to run into each other's arms, make a fashionable
elopement, and be happy for life; and I must own to you, Belfield, was there no other condition of our union, even this project should not deter me; but I have better hopes, provided you will be piloted by me; for believe me, my good friend, I am better acquainted with this coast than you are.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I doubt not your discretion, and shall implicitly surren∣der myself to your guidance.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Give me a proof of it then by retreating from this place immediately; 'tis my father's hour for walking, and I would not have you meet; besides, your brother is ex∣pected.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Ay, that brother, my Sophia, that brother brings vexa∣tion and regret whenever he is named; but I hope I need not dread a second injury in your esteem; and yet I know not how it is, but if I was addicted to superstition—

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: And if I was addicted to anger, I shou'd quarrel with you for not obeying my injunctions with more readiness.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I will obey thee, and yet 'tis difficult—Those lips, which thus have blest me, cannot dismiss me without—

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Belfield, don't you—well, then—mercy upon us! who's coming here?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: How, oh, yes! never fear; 'tis a friend; 'tis Violetta; 'tis a lady that I—

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: That you what, Mr. Belfield?—What lady is it? I never saw her in my life before.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: No, she is a foreigner, born in Portugal, tho' of an English family: the packet in which she was coming to England founder'd along side of our ship, and I was the instrument of saving her life: I interest myself much in her happiness, and I beseech you, for my sake, to be kind to her.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: He interests himself much in her happiness; he be∣seeches me, for his sake, to be kind to her—What am I to judge of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Madam, I ask pardon for this intrusion; but I have business with you of a nature that—I presume I'm not mistaked, you are the young lady I have been directed to, the daughter of Sir Benjamin Dove?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: I am, Madam; but you please to repose yourself in the house? I understand you are a stranger in this country. May I beg to know what commands you have for me? Mr. Belfield has made me acquainted with some circumstances relative to your story; and for his sake, Madam, I shall be proud to render you any service in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: For Mr. Belfield's sake, did you say, Madam? has Mr. Belfield named me to you, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Is there any wonder in that, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: No, none at all. In any man else, such confidence wou'd surprize me; but in Mr. Belfield 'tis natural; there is no wondering at what he does.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: You must pardon me: I find we think differently of Mr. Belfield. He left me but this minute, and in the kindest terms, recommended you to my friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: 'Twas he then, that parted from you as I came up; I thought so, but I was too much agitated to observe him—and I am confident he is too guilty to dare to look upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P:
Why so, Madam? for Heaven's sake, inform me what injuries you have received from Mr. Belfield; I must own
to you, I am much interested in finding him to be a man of honour

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: I know your situation, Madam, and I pity it; Provi∣dence has sent me here, in time, to save you, and to tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: What? To tell me what? O speak, or I shall sink with apprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: To tell you, that he is—my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Husband! your husband? what do I hear, ungenerous, base, deceitful Belfield! I thought he seem'd confounded at your appearance; every thing confirms his treachery; and I cannot doubt the truth of what you tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: A truth it is, Madam, that I must ever reflect-on with the most sorrowful regret.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Come, let me beg you to walk towards the house: I ask no account of this transaction of Mr. Belfield▪; I wou'd fain banish his name from my memory for ever; and you shall this instant be a witness to his peremptory dismission.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: And so, Sir, these are her ladyship's commands, are they?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: This is what I am commission'd by Lady Dove to tell you: what report shall I make to her?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P:
Even what you please, Mr. Paterson; mould it and model it to your liking; put as many palliatives, as you think proper▪ to sweeten it to her ladyship's taste; so you do but give her to understand that I neither can▪ nor will abandon my Sophia. Cease to think of her, indeed! What earthly power can exclude her idea from my thoughts; I am surpriz'd Lady Dove shou'd think of sending me such
a message and I wonder, Sir, that you shou'd consent to bring it.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Paterson, don't assume such a menacing air; nor practice on my temper too far in this business: I know both your situation and my own; consider, Sir, mine is a cause that would animate the most dastardly spi∣rit; your's is enough to damp the most courageous.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: A very short and sententious gentleman: but there is truth in his remark; mine is but a sorry commission, after all; the man's in the right to fight for his mistress; she's worth the venture; and if there was no way else to be quit of mine, I should be in the right to fight too: egad, I don't see why aversion shou'dn't make me as desperate as love makes him. Hell and fury! here comes my Venus.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Well, Paterson, what says the fellow to my message?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Says, Madam! I'm asham'd to tell you what he says: he's the arrantest boatswain that ever I convers'd with.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: But tell me what he says.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Every thing that scandal and scurrility can utter against you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Against me? What cou'd he say against me?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Modesty forbids me to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! the vile reprobate! I, that have been so guarded in my conduct, so discreet in my partialities, as to keep 'em secret, even from my own husband; but, I hope, he didn't venture to abuse my person.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: No, Madam, no; had he proceeded to such lengths▪ I coudn't in honour have put up with it; I hope, I have more spirit than to suffer any reflections upon your ladyship's personal accomplishments.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Wel; but did you say nothing in desence of my repu∣tation?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: No?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Not a syllable; trust me for that; 'tis the wisest way upon all tender topics to be silent; for, he who takes upon him to defend a lady's reputation, only publishes her favours to the world; and therefore I wou'd al∣ways leave that office to a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: 'Tis true; and, if Sir Benjamin had any heart—

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Come, come, my dear lady, don't be too severe upon Sir Benjamin; many men of no better appearance than Sir Benjamin, have shown themselves perfect heroes; I know a whole family, that with the limbs of ladies, have the hearts of lions. Who can tell but your husband may be one of this sort?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Ah!—

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Wel; but try him; tell him how you have been used, and see what his spirit will prompt him to do. Apro∣pos! here the little gentleman comes; if he wn't fight, 'tis but what you expect; if he will, who can tell where a lucky arrow may hit.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Sir Benjamin, I want to have a little discourse in pri∣vate with you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: With me, my lady?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: With you, Sir Benjamin; 'tis upon a matter of a very serious nature; pray sit down by me; I don't know how it is, my dear, but I have observed of late, with much concern, a great abatement in your regard for me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! fie, my lady, why do you think so? What rea∣son have you for so unkind a suspicion?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: 'Tis in vain for you to deny it; I am convinc'd you have done loving me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, now, I vow my dear, as I am a sinner, you do me wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Look'e, Sir Benjamin, love like mine is apt to be quick-sighted, and, I am persuaded, I am not deceived in my observation.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Indeed, and indeed, my Lady Dove, you accuse me wrongfully.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Mistake me not, my dear, I do not accuse you; I ac∣cuse myself; I am sensible, there are faults and imper∣fections in my temper.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! trifles; my dear, mere trifles.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Come, come, I know you have led but an uncomfort∣able life of late, and, I am afraid, I've been innocently, in some degree, the cause of it.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Far be it from me to contradict your ladyship, if you are pleas'd to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: I am sure it has been as I say; my over-fondness for you has been troublesome and vexatious; you hate con∣finement, I know you do; you are a man of spirit▪ and form'd to figure in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! you flatter me.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Nay, nay, there's no disguising it; you sigh for action; your looks declare it: this alteration in your habit and appearance puts it out of doubt; there is a certain quickness in your eye; 'twas the first symptom that attracted my regards; and, I am mistaken, Sir Ben∣jamin, if you don't possess as much courage as any man.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Your ladyship does me honour.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: I do you justice, Sir Benjamin.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Why, I believe, for the matter of courage, I have as much as my neighbours; but 'tis of a strange perverse quality; for as some spirits rise with the difficulties they are to encounter, my courage, on the contrary, is always greatest when there is least call for it.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! you shall never make me believe this, Sir Benja∣min; you cou'dn't bear to see me il-us'd, I'm positive you cou'dn't.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: 'Tis as well, however, not to be too sure of that. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: You cou'dn't be so mean spirited, as to stand by and hear your poor dear wife abus'd and insulted, and—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! no, by no means, 'twou'd break my heart; but who has abus'd you and insulted you, and—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Who? Why, this young Belfield that I told you of.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! never listen to him; a woman of your years shou'd have more sense than to mind what such ide young fleerers can say of you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: My years, Sir Benjamin! Why, you are more intolerable than he is; but let him take his course; let him run away with your daughter; it shal be no fur∣ther concern of mine to prevent him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: No, my dear, I've done that effectually.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: How so, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: By taking care he shan't run away with my estate at the same time. Some people lock their daughters up to prevent their eloping; I've gone a wiser way to work with mine, let her go loose, and lock'd up her fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: And, o' my conscience, I believe you mean to do the same by your wife; turn her loose upon the world▪ as you do your daughter; leave her to the mercy of every free-booter; let her be vilified and abusd; her honour, her reputation, mangled and torn by every paltry priva∣teering fellow that Fortune casts upon your coasts.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hold, my lady, hold! young Belfield didn't glance at your reputation, I hope; did he?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Indeed but he did tho', and therein I think every wife has a title to her husband's protection.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: True, my dear, 'tis our duty to plead, but your's to provide us with the brief.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: There are some insults, Sir Benjamin, that no man of spirit ought to put up with; and the imputation of being made a wittol of, is the most unpardonable of any.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Right, my dear, even truth▪ you know is not to be spoke at all times.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: How, Sir, wou'd you insinuate any thing to the dis∣paragement of my fidelity? but chuse your side, quarrel you must, either with him or with me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! if that's the alternative, what a deal of time have we wasted? Step with me into my library, and I'll pen him a challenge immediately.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: The cabbin, with a view of the sea, as before.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: HOW I have lov'd you, Lucy, and what I have suf∣fered on your account, you know well enough; and you shou'dn't now, when I am struggling to forget you, come to put me in mind of past afflictions: go, go, leave me: I pray you leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Nay, Philip, but hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: Hear you, ungrateful girl; you know it has been all my delight to hear you, to see you and to sit by your side; for hours have I done it; for whole days together: but those days are past; I must labour now for my live∣lihood; and, if you rob me of my time, you wrong me of my subsistence.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: O! Philip, I am undone if you don't protect me.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: Ah! Lucy, that, I fear, is past prevention.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: No, Philip, no, I am innocent; and, therefore, per∣secuted by the most criminal of men: I have disclosed all Mr. Belfield's artifices to Miss Sophia, and now am ter∣rified to death; I saw him follow me out of the Park, as I was coming hither, and I dare not return home alone; indeed, Philip, I dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: Well, Lucy, step in with me, and fear nothing; I see the 'squire is coming—He who can refuse his protection to a woman, may he never taste the blessings a woman can bestow.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Ay, 'tis she▪ Confusion follow her!—How perversely has she traversd my projects with Sophia!—By all that's resolute, I'll be reveng'd▪—My brother too return'd—Vexatious circumstance! there am I foil'd again—Since first I stepp'd out of the path of honour, what have I ob∣tain'd?—O treachery! treachery! if thou canst not in this world make us happy, better have remain'd that dull formal thing, an honest man, and trusted to what the fu∣ture might produce.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: So, fellow, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: A man, Sir; an honest man.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: A saucy one, methinks.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: The injurious are apt to think so; however, I ask par∣don: as your riches make you too proud, my honesty perhaps makes me too bold.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Oh! I know you now; you are son to that old fellow I thought proper to discharge from my farm: please to betake yourself from the door of your cabbin; there's a young woman within I must have a word with.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: If 'tis Lucy Waters you would speak with—

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: If, rascal! It is Lucy Waters that I would speak with; that I will speak with; and, spite of your insolence, com∣pel to answer whatever I please to ask, and go with me wherever I please to carry her.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: Then, Sir, I must tell you, poor as I am, she is under my protection: you see, Sir, I am arm'd; you have no right to force an entrance here; and, while I have life▪ you never shall.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Then be it at your peril, villain▪ if you oppose me.
SP.STAGE: Enters PATERSON, who beats down their swords.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: For shame, Mr. Belfield! what are you about? Tilting with this peasant.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Paterson, stand off▪

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Come, come, put-up your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Damnation, Sir! what do you mean? Do you turn against me? Give way, or by my soul, I'll run you through.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
