SP.P: Hey-day, what the devil ails you all? I thought the whole ship's company had sprung a mutiny. Master and I were taking a nap together for good fellowship; and you make such a damn'd clattering and clashing, there's no sleeping in peace for you.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Come, Mr. Paterson, will you please to bear me com∣pany, or stay with your new acquaintance?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Oh ho! my righteous nephew, is it you that are kick∣ing-up this riot? Why, you ungracious profligate, would you murder an honest lad in the door of his own house?—his castle—his castellum—Are these your fresh-water tricks▪

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Your language, Captain Ironsides, savours strongly of your profession; and I hold▪ both you, your occupation and opinion, equally vulgar and contemptible.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Come, Mr. Belfield, come; for Heaven's sake let us go home.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P:
My profession! Why what have you to say to my pro∣fession, you unsanctified whelp you? I hope 'tis an honest
vocation to fight the enemies of one's country; you, it seems, are for murdering the friends; I trust, it is not for such a skip-jack as thee art▪ to fleer at my profession. Master, did'st ever hear the like?

SP.SPEAKER: SKIFF.
SP.P: Never, Captain, never; for my own part, I am one of few words; but, for my own part, I always thought, that to be a brave sea-man, like your honour, was the greatest title an Englishman can wear.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Why so it is, Skiff: ahem!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Well Sir, I leave you to the enjoyment of your honours, so your servant. Sirrah, I shal find a time for you.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Hark'e, Sir, come back; one more word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Well Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Your father was an honest gentleman; your , tho' I say it, that shou'd not say it, was an angel; my eyes ae when I speak of her: an't you asham'd, rrah, to disgrace such parents▪ My nephew Bob, your brother, is as honest a lad, and as brave, as ever step between stem and stern; a'has a few faults indeed; as who is free? But you, Andrew, you are as false as a quick-sand; and as full of mischief as a fire-ship▪

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Captain▪ Ironsides▪ I have but little time to bestow on you; if you have nothing else to entertain me with, the sooner we part the better

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: No, Sir, one thing more, and I have done with you▪ they tell me you're parliament-man here for the borough of Knavestown: the Lord have mercy upon the nation, when such fellows as thou art are to be our law-makers—For my own part, I can shift; I'll take shipping, and live in Lapland, and be dry-nurse to a bear, rather than dwell in a country, where I am to be govern'd by such a thing as thou art.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: By your manners I should guess you had executed that office already; however, lose no time, sit out a new Charming Sally, and set sail for Lapland; 'tis the pro∣perest place for you to live in, and a bear the fittest com∣panion for you to keep.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Hark'e, Philip, I forgot to ask what all this stir was about.

SP.SPEAKER: PHILIP.
SP.P: Sir, if you please to walk in, I will inform you.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: With all my heart. A pragmatical, impertinent cox∣comb! Come, master, we'll fill a pipe, and hear the lad's story within doors. I never yet was ashamed of my pro∣fession, and I'll take care my profession shall have no rea∣son to be asham'd of me.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Madam, madam, will you not vouchsafe to give me a hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Unless you cou'd recall an act▪ no earthly power can cancel, all attempt at explanation is vain.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Yet, before we part for ever, obstinate, inexorable So∣phia, tell me what is my offence?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Answer yourself that question, Mr. Belfield; consult your own heart, consult your Violetta.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Now, on my life, she's meanly jealous of Violetta: that grateful woman has been warm in her commenda∣tions of me, and her distemper'd fancy turns that candou into criminality.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Hah I he seems confounded! guilty beyond all doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P:
By Heaven I'll no longer be the dupe to these bad hu∣mours: Lucy Waters, Violetta, every woman she sees
or hears, alarms her jealousy, overthrows my hopes, and rouses every passion into fury. Well, madam, at length I see what you allude to; I shall follow your advice, and consult my Violetta; nay more, consult my happiness; for with her, at least, I shall find repose; with you, I plainly see, there can be none.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: 'Tis very well, Sir; the only favour you can now grant me, is never to let me see you again; for, after what has pass'd between us, every time you intrude into my com∣pany, you will commit an insult upon good breeding and humanity.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Madam, I'll take care to give you no further offence.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Oh, my poor heart will break▪

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hey day, Sophia, what's the matter? what ails my child? who has offended you? did not I see the younger Belfield part from you just now?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: O, Sir! if you have any love for me, don't name that base▪ treacherous wretch to me any more.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P:
Upon my word I am young Mr. Belfield's most obse∣quious servant: a very notable confusion truly has he been pleased to make in my family. Lady Dove raves, Sophia cries; my wife calls him a saucy impudent fellow, my daughter says he's a base▪ treacherous wretch; from all which I am to conclude, that he has spoke too plain truths to the one, and told too many lies to the other: one lady is irritated because he has refusd favours; the other, perhaps, is afflicted because he has obtaind 'em. Lady Dove has peremptorily insisted upon my giving him a challenge; but, to say the truth, I had no great sto∣mach to the business, till this fresh provocation: I per∣ceive now I am growing into a most unaccountable rage; 'tis something so different from what I ever felt before,
that, for what I know, it may be courage and I mistake it for anger; I never did quarrel with any man, and hitherto no man ever quarrel'd with me: egad, if once I break the ice, it shan't stop here: if young Belfield doesn't prove me a coward, lady Dove shall see that I am a man of spirit.—Sure I see my gentleman coming hither again.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: What meanness, what infatuation possesses me, that I should resolve to throw myself once more in her way! but she's gone, and yet I may escape with credit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Ay▪ there he is sure enough: by the mass I don't like him: I'll listen a while and discover what sort of a hu∣mour he is in.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I am ashamed of this weakness: I am determined to as∣sume a proper spirit, and act as becomes a man upon this occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Upon my soul I'm very sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Now am I so distracted between love, rage and disap∣pointment, that I cou'd find in my heart to sacrifice her, myself, and all mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Lord ha' mercy upon us, I'd better steal off and leave him to himself.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: And yet perhaps all this may proceed from an excess of fondness in my Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Upon my word you are blest with a most happy as∣surance.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Something may have dropp'd from Violetta to alarm her jealousy, and, working upon the exquisite sensibility of her innocent mind, may have brought my sincerity into question.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: I don't understand a word of all this.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Now cou'd I fall at her feet for pardon, tho' I know not in what I have offended; I have not the heart to move. Fie upon it! What an arrant coward has love made me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: A coward does he say? I am heartily rejoicd to hear it: if I must needs come to action, pray Heaven it be with a coward! I'll ev'n take him while he is in the humour, for fear he shou'd recover his courage, and I lose mine.—So, Sir, your humble servant, Mr. Bel∣field! I'm glad I have found you, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Sir Benjamin, your most obedient. Pray what are your commands now you have found me?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hold! hold! don't come any nearer: don't you see I am in a most prodigious passion? Fire and fury, what's the reason you have made all this disorder in my house▪ my daughter in tears; my wife in fits; every thing in an uproar; and all your doing. Do you think I'll put-up with this treatment? If you suppose you have a coward to deal with, you'll find yourself mistaken; greatly mis∣take let me tell you, Sir! Mercy upon me, what a passion I am in▪ In short, Mr. Belfield, the honour of my house is concern'd, and I must and will have satis∣faction▪—I think this is pretty well to set in with; I'm horribly out of breath; I sweat at every pore. What great fatigues do men of courage undergo!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Look'e, Sir Benjamin, I don't rightly comprehend what you wou'd be at; but if you think I have injurd you, few words are best; disputes between men of honour are soon adjusted; I'm at your service, in any way you think fit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: How you fly-out now! Is that giving me the satisfac∣tion I require? I am the person injur'd in this matter, and as such, have a right to be in a passion; but I see neither right nor reason why you, who have done the wrong, shou'd be as angry as I▪ who have receiv'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I suspect I have totally mistaken this honest gentle∣man; he only wants to build some reputation with his wife upon this renconter, and 'twould be inhuman not to gratify him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: What shall I do now? Egad I seem to have pos'd him: this plaguy sword sticks so hard in the scabbard—Well, come-forth, rapier, 'tis but one thrust; and what shou'd a man fear that has Lady Dove for his wife?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Hey-day! is the man mad? Put up your sword, Sir Benjamin, put it up and don't expose yourself in this manner.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: You shall excuse me, Sir; I have had some difficulty in drawing it, and am determin'd now to try what metal it made of. So come on, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Really this is too ridiculous; I tell you, Sir Benjamin, I am in no humour for these follies. I've done no wrong to you or yours: on the contrary great wrong has been done to me; but I have no quarrel with you; so, pray, put▪up your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: And I tell you, Mr. Belfield, 'tis in vain to excuse yourself—The less readiness he shews so much the more resolution I feel.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Well, Sir Knight, if such is your humour, I wn't spoil your longing. So have at you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Ah! [Shrieks.]

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Sir Benjamin, I never fight in lady's com∣pany. Why I protest you are a perfect Amadis de Gaul▪ a Don Quixote in heroism, and the presence of this your Dulcinea renders you invincible.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P:
Oh, my Lady, is it you? don't be alarm'd my dear; 'tis all over: a small fracas between this gentleman and
myself! that's all; don't be under any surprize; I believe the gentleman has had enough; I believe he is perfectly satisfied with my behaviour, and I persuade myself you will have no cause for the future to complain of his. Mr. Belfield, this is Lady Dove.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Madam, to a generous enemy 'tis mean to deny justice, or with-hold applause. You are happy in the most valiant of defenders; gentle as you may find him in the tender passions, to a man, Madam, he acquits himself like a man. Sir Benjamin Dove, in justice to your merit, I am ready to make any submission to this lady you shall please to impose. If you suffer her to bully you after this, you deserve to be hen peck'd all the days of your life.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Say no more, my dear Bob; I shall love you for this the longest hour I have to live.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: If I have done you any service, promise me only one hour's conversation with your lovely daughter, and make what use of me you please.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Here's my hand, you shall have it; leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: What am I to think of all this? It can't well be a con∣trivance; and yet 'tis strange that yon little animal shou'd have the assurance to face a man, and be so bashful at a renconter with a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, Lady Dove, what are you musing upon? you see you are obey'd; the honour of your family is vindicated: slow to enter into these affairs; being once engag'd, I pertinaciously conduct them to an issue.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Sir Benjamin,—I—I—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Here▪ Jonathan, do you hear, set my things ready in the library; make haste.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: I say, Sir Benjamin, I think—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, let's hear what it is you think.—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Bless us all, why you snap one up so—I say, I think, my dear, you have acquitted yourself tolerably well, and I am perfectly satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Humph! you think I have done tolerably well, I think so too; do you apprehend me? Tolerably! for this business that you think tolerably well done is but half concluded, let me tell you: nay, what some wou'd call the toughest part of the undertaking remains unfinish'd; but, I dare say, with your concurrence, I shall find it easy enough.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: What is it you mean to do with my concurrence, what mighty project does your wise brain teem with?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Nay, now I reflect on't again, I don't think there'll be any need of your concurrence, for nolens or volens▪ I'm determin'd it shall be done: In short, this it is, I am un∣alterably resolvd from this time forward, Lady Dove, to be sole and absolute in this house, master of my own ser∣vants, father to my own child, and sovereign lord and governor, Madam, over my own wife.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: You are?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: I am. Gods! Gods! what a pityful contemptible figure does a man make under petticoat government. Perish he that's mean enough to stoop to such indignities. I am determin'd to be free.—(PATERSON enters and whispers LADY DOVE.)—Hah! how's this Mr. Pater∣son? What liberties are these you take with my wife, and before my face? No more of these freedoms I beseech you, Sir, as you expect to answer it to a husband, who will have no secrets whisper'd to his wife, to which he is not privy; nor any appointments made▪ in which he is not a party.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Hey-day! what a change of government is here! Egad, I'm very glad on't—I've no notion of a female administra∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: What insolence is this, Sir Benjamin; what ribaldry do you shock my ears with? Let me pass, Sir, I'll stay no longer in the same room with you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Not in the same room, nor under the same roof shall you long abide, unless you reform your manners▪ how∣ever, for the present, you must be content to stay where you are.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: What, Sir, will you imprison me in my own house? I'm sick; I'm ill; I'm suffocated; I want air; I must and will walk into the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Then, Madam, you must find some better weapon than your fan to parry my sword with: this pass I defend: what, do'st think, after having encountered a man, I shall turn my back upon a woman! No, Madam, I have ven∣tured my life to defend your honour; 'twould be hard if I wanted spirit to protect my own.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: You monster, would you draw your sword upon a woman?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Unless it has been your pleasure to make me a monster, Madam, I am none.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Would you murder me, you inhuman brute? would you murder your poor fond defenceless wife?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Nor tears, nor threats, neither scolding, nor soothing, shall shake me from my purpose: your yoke, Lady Dove, has lai too heavy upon my shoulders; I can support it no longer: to-morrow, Madam, you leave this house.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Will you break my heart, you tyrant? will you turn me out of doors to starve, you barbarous man?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P:
Oh! never fear; you will fare to the full as well as you did in your first husband's time; in your poor▪ dear dead Mr. Searcher's time. You told me once you prizd
the paltry grey-hound that hung at his button-hole, more than all the jewels my folly had lavish'd upon you. I take you at your word; you shall have your bawble, and I will take back all mine; they'll be of no use to you here∣after.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: O! Sir Benjamin, Sir Benjamin, for mercy's sake turn me not out of your doors! I will be obedient, gentle, and complying for the future; don't shame me; on my knees, I beseech you don't.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Mr. Belfield, I am heartily glad to see you; don't go back, Sir; you catch us indeed a little unawares; but these situations are not uncommon in well▪ordered fami∣lies; rewards and punishments are the life of govern∣ment, and the authority of a husband must be upholde.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: I confess, Sir Benjamin, I was greatly surpriz'd at finding Lady Dove in that attitude: but I never pry into family-secrets; I had much rather suppose your lady was on her knees to intercede with you in my behalf, than be told she was reduc'd to that humble posture for any rea∣son that affects herself.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Sir, you are free to suppose what you please for Lady Dove; I'm willing to spare you that trouble on my account; and therefore I tell you plainly, if you will sign and seal your articles this night, to-morrow morn∣ing Sophia shall be yours: I'm resolv'd that the self-same day, which consecrates the redemption of my liberty, shall confirm the surrender of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: O! Mr. Belfield, I beseech you, intercede with this dear cruel man in my behalf; wou'd you believe that he harbours a design of expelling me his house, on the very day too when he purposes celebrating the nuptials of his daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Come, Sir Benjamin, I must speak to you now as a friend in the nearest connection; I beg you will not damp our happiness with so melancholy an event: I will venture to pledge myself for her ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, for your sake perhaps I may prolong her de∣parture for one day; but I'm determin'd, if she does stay to-morrow, she shall set the first dish upon the table; if 'tis only to shew the company what a refractory wife in the hands of a man of spirit may be brought to submit to. Our wives, Mr. Belfield, may teaze us and vex us, and still escape with impunity; but if once they thoroughly provoke us, the charm breaks, and they are lost for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: WHAT you tell me, Fanny, gives me great concern that Mr. Francis shou'd think to seduce the inno∣cence of my child for a paltry bribe: what can have pass'd to encourage him to put such an affront upon you?

SP.SPEAKER: FANNY.
SP.P: Till this proposal, which I tell you of, I always took Mr. Francis for one of the best-behav'd modestest young men I had ever met with.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: To say the truth, Fanny, so did I; but the world is full of hypocrisy, and our acquaintance with him has been very short—(Enters FRANCIS.)—Hark'e, young man, a word with you! What is it I or my children have done to offend you?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Offend me! what is it you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: When your vessel was stranded upon our coast, did we take advantage of your distress? On the contrary, wasn't this poor hut thrown open to your use, as a receptacle for your treasures, and a repose for your fatigues? Have either those treasures▪ or that repose been invaded? Whom amongst you have we robb'd or defrauded?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: None, none; your honesty has been as conspicuous as your hospitality.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Why then, having receiv'd no injury, do you seek to do one? an injury of the basest nature—You see there a poor girl, whose only portion in this world is her inno∣cence, and of that you have sought to—

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P:
Hold; nor impute designs to me which I abhor: you say your daughter has no portion but her innocence;
assur'd of that, I ask none else; and, if she can forgive the stratagem I have made use of, I am ready to atone for it by a life devoted to her service.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'm happy to find you are the man I took you for, and cannot discommend your caution; so that if you like my daughter, and Fanny is consenting—But, soft! who have we got here?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: I wish Mr. Paterson was further for interrupting us just now.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Pray, good people, isn't there a lady with you of the name of Violetta?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: There is.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Can you direct me to her? I have business with her of the utmost consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: Fanny, you and Mr. Francis step in and let the lady know.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: If it's no offence, Mr. Paterson, allow me to ask you whether there is any hope of our young gentleman here▪ who is just return'd, succeeding in his addresses to Miss Dove?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Certainly none, Master Goodwin.

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: I'm heartily sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: I find you are a stranger to the reasons▪ which make against it; but how are you interested in his success?

SP.SPEAKER: GOODWIN.
SP.P: I am a witness of his virtues, and consequently not in∣different to his success.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Madam, I presume your name is Violetta.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: It is, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: I wait upon you, Madam, at Miss Dove's desire, and as a particular friend of Mr. Andrew Belfield.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Madam!—

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Pray▪ proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: To intreat the favour of your company at Cropley-castle upon business, wherein that lady and gentleman are intimately concerned: I presume, Madam, you guess what I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I can't easily guess how I can possibly be a party in any business between Miss Dove and Mr. Bel∣field. I thought all intercourse between those persons was now ntirely at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Oh! no, Madam, by no means; the affair is far from being at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: How, Sir! not at an end?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: No, Madam; on the contrary, from Sir Benjamin's great anxiety for the match, and, above all, from the very seasonable intelligence you ws so good to as commu∣nicate to Miss Sophia, I am not without hopes that Mr. Andrew Belfield will be happy enough to conquer all her scruples, and engage her consent to marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P:
Indeed! but▪ pray, Sir, those scruples of Miss Dove's, which you flatter yourself Mr. Belfield will so happily conquer, how is it that ladies in this country reconcile
themselves to such matters? I shou'd have thought such an obstacle utterly insurmountable.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, Madam, Miss Dove has had some doubts and difficulties to contend with; but duty you know—and, as I said before, you, Madam, you have been a great friend to Mr. Belfield; you have forwarded matters surprisingly.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: It is very surprising, truly, if I have.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: You seem greatly stagger'd at what I tell you; I see you are no stranger to the principles upon which young ladies frequently act in this country: I believe, Madam, in England, as many, or more, matches are made from pique▪ than for love; and, to say the truth, I take this of Miss Dove's to be one of that sort. There is a cer∣tain person, you know, who will feel upon this occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Yes; I well know there is a certain person, who will feel upon this occasion; but, are the sufferings of that unhappy one to be converted into raillery and amuse∣ment?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Oh! Madam! the ladies will tell you, that therein consists the very luxury of revenge.—But, I beseech you, have the goodness to make haste; my friend Mr. Belfield may stand in need of your support.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Thus insulted I can contain myself no longer. Upon what infernal shore am I cast! into what society of dae∣mons am I fall'n! that a woman, whom by an act of honour, I wou'd have redeem'd from misery and ruin, shou'd have the insolence, the inhumanity, to invite me to be a spectatress of her marriage with my own hus∣band!

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: With your husband! What do I hear? Is Mr. An∣drew Belfield your husband?

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Ay; do you doubt it? Wou'd I cou'd say he was not.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Just Heaven! you then are the Violetta, you are the Portuguese lady I have heard so much of, and married to Mr. Belfield; base and perfidious!—Why, Madam, both Miss Dove and myself conceiv'd that 'twas the young adventurer with whom you suffer'd shipwreck, that—

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: What! Lewson, the brave, generous, honourable, Lewson?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Lewson! Lewson! as sure as can be you mean young Belfield▪ for now the recollection strikes me, that I've heard he took that name before he quitted England. That Lewson, Madam, whom we believ'd you married to, is Robert Belfield, and younger brother to your hus∣band.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Mercy defend me! into what distress had this mutual mistake nearly involvd us?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Come then, Madam, let us lose no time, but fly with all dispatch to Cropley-castle; I have a post-chaise wait∣ing, which will convey us thither in a few minutes: but before we go I'll step in and direct these good people to find young Belfield, and send him after us—Old Ironsides and all must be there.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV3.P: Let me reflect upon my fate—Wedded, betray'd, abandon'd! at once a widow and a wie. All that my soul held dear in the same hour obtain'd and lost. O false▪ false, Belfield! Strong indeed must be that passion, and deeply seated in my heart▪ which even thy treachery cou'd not eradicate! Twice shipwreck'd, twice rescu'd from the jaws of Death; just Heaven! I do not, dare not murmur, nor can I doubt but that thy hand invisibly is stretchd-forth to save me, and thro' this labyrinth of sorrow to conduct me to repose.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Now, Madam, if you'll trust yourself to my convoy, I'll bring you into harbour, where you shal never suffer shipwreck more.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Upon these terms and stipulations, Lady Dove, I consent to your remaining at Cropley-castle. Enjoy you your own prerogative, and leave me in possession of mine; above all things, my dear, I must insist that Mr. Paterson be henceforward consider'd as my friend and companion, not your ladyship's.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Nay, but indeed and indeed, my dear Sir Benjamin, this is being too hard with me, to debar me the common gratifications of every woman of distinction: Mr. Pater∣son, you know, is my very particular friend.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: 'Tis for his being so very particular, my dear, that I object to him.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Friendship, Sir Benjamin, is the virtuous recreation of delicate and susceptible minds; wou'd you envy me that innocent pleasure? Why you know, my dearest, that your passion for me, which was once so violent, is now sof∣ten'd and subsided into mere friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: True, my dear; and, therefore, I am afraid lest my love having, by easy degrees, slacken'd into friendship, his friendship should, by as natural a transition, quicken into love; say no more, therefore▪ upon this point, but leave me to Mr. Paterson and Mr. Paterson to me—go—send Sophia to me—oh here she comes: your ladyship need not be present at our conference; I think my own daughter surely appertains to my province, and not yours. Good morning to you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Wel, daughter, are yo prepar'd to comply with my desires, and give your hand to Andrew Belfield this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Sir?—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: My heart is fixd upon this event; I have watch'd late and early to bring it to bear; and you'll find, my child, when you come to peruse your marriage settlement, how tenderly I have consulted your happiness in this match.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Alas! I should never think of searching for happiness amongst deeds and conveyances; 'tis the man, and not his money, that is likely to determine my lot.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, and is not Mr. Belfield a man? a fine man, as I take it, he is, and a fine estate I'm sure he has got; then it lies so handy and contiguous to my own; only a hedge betwixt us; think of that, Sophy, only a hedge that parts his manor from mine; then consider, likewise, how this alliance will accommodate matters in the borough of Knavestown, where I and my family have stood three contested elections with his, and lost two of them; that sport will now be at an end, and our interests will be consolidated by this match, as well as our estates.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Still you mistake my meaning; I talk of the quali∣ties of a man, yo of his possessions; I require▪ in a husband, good morals, good nature, and good sense; what has all this to do with cntiguous estates, connected in∣terests, and contested elections?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: I don't rightly understand what you would have, child; but this I wel know, that if money alone will not make a woman happy, 'twill always purchase that that will. I hope, Sophy, y've done thinking of that rambling, idle young fellow, Bob Belfield.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Perish all thought of him for ever! nothing can be more contrary, more impossible in nature, than my uni∣on with young Belfield: age, ugliness, ill-nature, bring any thing to my arms, rather than him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: But why so angry with him, child? this violent detes∣ation and abhorrence is as favourable a symptom as any reasonable lover cou'd wish for.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Joy to you, Sir Benjamin! all joy attend you both! the bridegroom by this time is arrivd; we saw his equi∣page enter the avenue as ours drove into the court.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Mr. Paterson, Sir, I know not if yet your friend is to be a bridegroom; I find my daughter here so cold and un∣complying; for my own part▪ I don't know how I shal look Mr. Belfield in the face.

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Fear nothing, Sir Benjamin: make haste and receive your son-in-law, I have news to communicate to Miss Dove, which I am confident will dispose her to comply with your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I shal leave her to your tutorage; this obliging gentleman undertakes not only for my wife, but my daughter too.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: I am surprized, Mr. Paterson—

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Hold, madam, for one moment: I have made a disco∣very of the last importance to your welfare: you are in an error with regard to young Belfield—Violetta, the lady you believed him married to, is here in the house; I have brought her hither at your request, and from her I learn that 'tis his elder brother is her husand; he who this very morning, but for my discovery, had been yours also.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: What's this you tell me, Sir? where is this lady? where is Violetta? where is young Belfield?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Violetta, Madam, I have put under safe convoy, and by this time your waiting-woman has lodg'd her privately in the closet of your bed-chamber: there you will find her, and learn the whole process of this providential es∣cape. I'll only speak a word to Sir Benjamin, and come to you without any further delay.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter SIR BENJAMIN DOVE and BELFIELD SENIOR.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Paterson, what says my daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: PATERSON.
SP.P: Every thing that becomes an obedient daughter to say; so that if this gentleman is not made completly happy within this hour, the fault will lie at his door, and not with Miss Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: This is good news, Paterson; but I am impatient to have the ceremony concluded; the bells are ringing, the parson is waiting, and the equipages are at the door: step▪up to Sophia, and tell her to hasten; and hark'e, my friend, as you go by Lady Dove's door, give her a call, do you mind me, only a call at the door: don't you go in; she's busy at work upon a large parcel of ribbands, which I've given her to make into wedding favours; she'll be very angry if you go into her chamber. Go, go, get you gone.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: How comes it to pass, Sir Benjamin, that Mr. Paterson is become so necessary an agent in the female affairs of your family? I confess to you my pride is wounded, when I find I am to thank him for your daughter's consent to marry me. The man that can prevail upon a woman to act against her liking, what may he not persuade her to do with it?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P:
Your remark is just; Paterson has certainly some secret
faculty of persuasion; and all that can be said is, that 'tis better to see your danger before marriage▪ than to be feel∣ing it out, as I have done, afterwards.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter CAPTAIN IRONSIDES and BELFIELD JUNIOR.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: What, old acquaintance, are you come to rejoice with me on this occasion?—Bob Belfield too as I live; you are both heartily welcome.—I could have spar'd their visit notwithstanding▪

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: My brother here; vexation!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Sir Benjamin, I come now to claim your promise of one hour's conversation with your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: The devil you do!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Ridiculous!

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: To you, Sir, obligations of this sort may be matter of ridicule; but while I religiously observe all promises I make to others, I shall expect others to be as observant of those they make to me.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Sir, I have a most profound veneration for your prin∣ciples, and am happy to find your understanding so much cultivated by travel; but in spite of your address, you will find it rather difficult to induce me to wave my right in Miss Dove in favour of a profest adventurer.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Shameless, unfeeling man! an adventurer do you call me? You, whose unbrotherly persecution drove me to this hazardous, this humiliating occupation?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Sirrah! Bob! no reflections upon privateering; it has lind your pockets well, you young rogue; and you may tell your fine brother there that we have landed treasure enough upon his estate to buy the fee-simple of it; ay, and for what I know, of Sir Wiseacre's here into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: What's that you say, Captain Ironsides? Let's have a word in a corner with you.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Look'e, Sir, if you conceive yourself wrong'd by me, there is but one way—You know your remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I know your meaning, brother; and to demonstrate how much greater my courage is than yours, I must confes to you I dare not accept your proposal.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: No, no, I've given him enough of that I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Bob Belfield, if I did not know thee for a lad of mettle, I shou'dn't tell what to make of all this: for my own part, I understand none of your scruples and refinements, not I; a man is a man; and if I take care to give an af∣front to no man, I think, I have a right to take an affront from no man.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Come, gentlemen, suspend your dispute; here comes my daughter, let her decide betwixt you.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Let me receive my sentence from her lips, and I will submit to it.
SP.STAGE: Enter SOPHIA, PATERSON, and LADY DOVE.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Here's a young gentleman, daughter, that will take no denial; he comes to forbid the bans just when you are both going into the church to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Upon my word this is something extraordinary. What are the gentleman's reasons for this behaviour?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: He claims a sort of promise from me that he shou'd be indulg'd in an hour's conversation with you, before you give your hand to his brother.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: An hour's conversation! What little that gentleman can have to say to me I believe may be said in a very few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: I think, brother, this conversation don't promise a great deal.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: In the first place then I own to this gentleman and the company present, that there was a time, when I enter∣tain'd the highest opinion of his merit. Nay, I will not scruple to confess that I had conceiv'd a regard for him of the tenderest sort.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: And pray, young lady, how came my nephew to for∣feit your good opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: By a conduct, Sir, that must for ever forfeit not my esteem only, but yours and all mankind's: I am sorry to be his accuser, but I will appeal to you, Mr. Belfield, who are his brother, whether it is reconcilable either to honour or humanity to prosecute an affair of marriage with one woman, when you are previously and indispen∣sibly engaged to another?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Humph▪

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Yet this, Sir, is the treatment I have receiv'd: judge, therefore, if I can desire or consent to have any long con∣versation with a gentleman who is under such engage∣ments▪ nay, whom I can prove actually married to another woman in this very house, and ready to vouch the truth of what I assert. Judge for me, Mr. Belfield; cou'd you believe any man capable of such complicated, such inconceivable villany?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Heaven's! This touches me too closely.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Sir, I wou'd fain know what excuse you can have for this behaviour; I can tell you, Sir, I don't understand it.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY DOVE.
SP.P: Oh! fie! fie upon you, Mr. Belfield! I wonder you are not ashamd to show your face in this family.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Who desired you to put in your oar?

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Why, sirrah, wou'd not one wife content you? 'tis enough in all reason for one man; is it not, Sir Benjamin?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Sir, when it is prov'd I am married, accuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Look'e Bob, I don't accuse you for marrying, 'twas an indiscretion and I can forgive it; but to deny it▪ is a meanness, and I abhor it.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Mr. Belfield, do you say nothing upon this occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Paterson, I am strck to the heart; I cannot support my guilt▪ I am married to Violetta; save me the confusion of relating it; this dishonourable engagement for ever I renounce, nor will I rest till I have made atonement to an injur'd wife. Madam, I beg leave to withdraw for a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Hold, Sir, this contrivance is of your forging; you have touch'd me too near; and now, if you dare draw your sword, follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Hold, gentlemen, you forget the lady is now in the house; she is a witness, that will effectually put an end to your dispute: I will conduct her hither.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: I agree to it.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Hark'e nephew, I shrewdly suspect you have been laying a train to blow yourself up: if once Bob comes fairly alongside of you, you'll find your quarters too hot to hold you: I never yet found my boy out in a lye, and shan't tamely see a le impos'd upon him; for, while he is honest and I have breath, he shall never want a friend to stand by him▪ or a father to protect him.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: Mr. Paterson, explain my story, I will depart this in∣stant in search of Violetta.

SP.SPEAKER: SOPHIA.
SP.P: Stay! I conjure you; stay, turn, and look back upon this lady, before you go.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: My wife!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Hey-day! here's a turn.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: I thought how 'twou'd be.

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, your faithful, your forsaken wife.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: How shall I look upon you? What shall I say? Where shall I hide my confusion? Oh! take me to your arms, and in that soft shelter let me find forgiveness and protection!

SP.SPEAKER: VIOLETTA.
SP.P: Be this your only punishment! and this.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Was it then a sister I preserv'd from death?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: What's this I hear? O! brother, can you pardon too?

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: Be indeed a brother, and let this providential event be the renovation of your friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: What shall I say to you, Madam? [To Sophia.] Paterson, you know my heart; bear witness to its re∣morse. By Heav'n my secret resolution was, instantly to have departed in search of this my injurd wife; but I'm not worthy even of your resentment: here is one that merits▪ and returns your love▪

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P:
Come, god-daughter, we can never say the fleet's fairly come to an anchor, while the admiral's ship is out at sea. [Presenting Belfield junior.] My nephew here is as honest a lad as lives, and loves you at the soul of him: give him your hand, and I'll broach the last chest
of dollars, to make him a fortune deserving you. What say you, my old friend?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: Here's my hand! I've spoke the word; she's his own▪ Lady Dove, I wn't hear a syllable to the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: Then, the galleon is thy own, boy—What shou'd an old fellow like me do with money? Give me a warm night▪cap, a tiff of punch, and an elbow-chair in your chimney-corner▪ and I'll lay up for the rest of my days.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD JUNIOR.
SP.P: How shall I give utterance to my gratitude▪ or my love?
SP.STAGE: Enter GOODWIN, FANNY, FRANCIS, PHILIP, and LUCY.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR BENJAMIN DOVE.
SP.P: So, so! more work for the parson.

SP.SPEAKER: IRONSIDES.
SP.P: What! Francis, hast thou chosen a mate, and art bound upon a matrimonial cruize as well as thy master?

SP.SPEAKER: FRANCIS.
SP.P: Ay, Sir; so he is happy as well as myself, and has no objection to my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: BELFIELD SENIOR.
SP.P: What! Are you all assembled to overwhelm me with confusion? Like some poor culprit, surrounded by a crowd of witnesses I stand convicted and appall'd. But all your wrongs shall be redress'd; your's Goodwin; Phi∣lip's; Lucy's: my whole life shall be employ'd in acts of justice and atonement. Virtue and this virtuous woman were my first ruling passions.

Q.L: Now they resume their social soft controul,
And love and happiness possess my soul.
